column4: also if you type whereis name_of_application it will give you its location
detlef@MD97600:~$ whereis Tunapie; Tunapie: (empty)
is it run with a T? or t
whereis works best if you do sudo updatedb and that the application is installed via deb or repositories
In both direcotries Tunapie is displayes with a capital first letter.
I didn't say folder, I meant the actual application
All my applications on this computer are installed via Ubuntu repositories. This morning at 07:35 local time my computer did automatically run 'updatedb'.
I missed what the problem you are having exactly.
Why are there two desktop configuration files: /usr/share/app-install/desktop/Tunapie and /usr/share/applications/Tunapie?
one is the link one is the location of the binary.
mc does not indicate that one of the two files tunapie.desktop is a link.
I assume, since not all applications are identically the same way of how they are located.
I do not know how to put to use your message.
I don't quite get you..

I read your message: "I assume, since not all applications are identically the same way of how they are located." but I do not understand if there is any meaningful contents in it. Please say it in other words.
I mean, different applications are located differently.
I am speaking about one and the same application: The name of the application is 'Tunapie'.
not familiar with Tunapie sorry.
I do know its location is /usr/share/tunapie/
You missed the point: I took 'Tunapie' only as an example. If you do not know Tunapie, you still could answer my question if you were knowledgeable enough.

as I said, different applications install differently, as far as tunapie all I know is that the location of the application resides in /usr/share/tunapie/ , I am a volunteer like anyone else, I'm not a guru, thank you.
and tenX any discussions please take it to #ubuntu-offtopic
